#Text=Preface
#Text=I was a boy when I went through the wonderful adventures herein set down .

#Text=With the memory of my boyish feelings strong upon me , I present my book specially to boys , in the earnest hope that they may derive valuable information , much pleasure , great profit , and unbounded amusement from its pages .
#Text=One word more .

#Text=If there is any boy or man who loves to be melancholy and morose , and who cannot enter with kindly sympathy into the regions of fun , let me seriously advise him to shut my book and put it away .
#Text=It is not meant for him .
#Text=RALPH ROVER
#Text=CHAPTER I.
#Text=The beginning -- My early life and character -- I thirst for adventure in foreign lands and go to sea .
#Text=Roving has always been , and still is , my ruling passion , the joy of my heart , the very sunshine of my existence .

#Text=In childhood , in boyhood , and in man 's estate , I have been a rover ; not a mere rambler among the woody glens and upon the hill-tops of my own native land , but an enthusiastic rover throughout the length and breadth of the wide wide world .
#Text=It was a wild , black night of howling storm , the night in which I was born on the foaming bosom of the broad Atlantic Ocean .
#Text=My father was a sea-captain ; my grandfather was a sea-captain ; my great-grandfather had been a marine .

#Text=Nobody could tell positively what occupation his father had followed ; but my dear mother used to assert that he had been a midshipman , whose grandfather , on the mother 's side , had been an admiral in the royal navy .
#Text=At anyrate
#Text=we knew that , as far back as our family could be traced , it had been intimately connected with the great watery waste .
#Text=Indeed this was the case on both sides of the house ; for my mother always went to sea with my father on his long voyages , and so spent the greater part of her life upon the water .
#Text=Thus it was , I suppose , that I came to inherit a roving disposition .

#Text=Soon after I was born , my father , being old , retired from a seafaring life , purchased a small cottage in a fishing village on the west coast of England , and settled down to spend the evening of his life on the shores of that sea which had for so many years been his home .
#Text=It was not long after this that I began to show the roving spirit that dwelt within me .

#Text=For some time past my infant legs had been gaining strength , so that I came to be dissatisfied with rubbing the skin off my chubby knees by walking on them , and made many attempts to stand up and walk like a man ; all of which attempts , however , resulted in my sitting down violently and in sudden surprise .

#Text=One day I took advantage of my dear mother 's absence to make another effort ; and , to my joy , I actually succeeded in reaching the doorstep , over which I tumbled into a pool of muddy water that lay before my father 's cottage door .

#Text=Ah , how vividly I remember the horror of my poor mother when she found me sweltering in the mud amongst a group of cackling ducks , and the tenderness with which she stripped off my dripping clothes and washed my dirty little body !

#Text=From this time forth my rambles became more frequent , and , as I grew older , more distant , until at last I had wandered far and near on the shore and in the woods around our humble dwelling , and did not rest content until my father bound me apprentice to a coasting vessel , and let me go to sea .
#Text=For some years I was happy in visiting the sea-ports , and in coasting along the shores of my native land .
#Text=My Christian name was Ralph , and my comrades added to this the name of Rover , in consequence of the passion which I always evinced for travelling .

#Text=Rover was not my real name , but as I never received any other I came at last to answer to it as naturally as to my proper name ; and , as it is not a bad one , I see no good reason why I should not introduce myself to the reader as Ralph Rover .
#Text=My shipmates were kind , good-natured fellows , and they and I got on very well together .
#Text=They did , indeed , very frequently make game of and banter me , but not unkindly ; and I overheard them sometimes saying that Ralph Rover was a " queer , old-fashioned fellow . "
#Text=This , I must confess , surprised me much , and I pondered the saying long , but could come at no satisfactory conclusion as to that wherein my old-fashionedness lay .
#Text=It is true I was a quiet lad , and seldom spoke except when spoken to .

#Text=Moreover , I never could understand the jokes of my companions even when they were explained to me : which dulness in apprehension occasioned me much grief ; however , I tried to make up for it by smiling and looking pleased when I observed that they were laughing at some witticism which I had failed to detect .
#Text=I was also very fond of inquiring into the nature of things and their causes , and often fell into fits of abstraction while thus engaged in my mind .
#Text=But in all this I saw nothing that did not seem to be exceedingly natural , and could by no means understand why my comrades should call me " an old-fashioned fellow . "
